March 9th 1994

singling out one industry in order to try to finance this health care bill is just totally unfair a spontaneous demonstration from the tobacco industry we're being asked to to pay for the entire Clinton health fair fair package and it's just totally unfair well not entirely spontaneous

actually the tobacco industry gave its workers the day off and chartered buses so they could come to Washington to protest because our fair to single out one tax one industry can pay for the increased health care costs by putting us out of business

tonight the tobacco industry gasping for air this is ABC News Nightline reporting from Washington Ted Koppel the battle has been going on for so many years that it is a surprise sometimes to realize that it's still in progress the tobacco

oh industry staunchly insisting that the evidence on smoking and lung disease or heart disease is suggestive but not conclusive more and more however the industry's apologists are coming to resemble those Japanese soldiers discovered on remote Islands 20 and 30 years after the end of World War Two they had never realized the war was over the war against smoking of course is far from over 50 million Americans still smoke 400,000 a years suffered tobacco-related

deaths but a significant corner has been turned almost 40 years of medical warnings and anti-smoking campaigns Decades of lawsuits and public service announcements and endless nagging from concerned family members and friends have indeed convinced millions of us to quit the tobacco industry has lost significant ground they in their workers are worried about losing even more specifically the imposition of a new 75

five cents a pack tax on cigarettes to help Finance the Clinton Health Plan and so today they came to Washington my colleague Chris Peoria and I have spent a good part of the day talking to people on both sides of the issue Chris in the field and I here in the studio

on a chilly damp uncomfortable day they came from the Carolinas Virginia Kentucky and other tobacco strongholds 16,000 who work in the factories and Farms they marched from the White House to the Capitol the latest soldiers or perhaps Pawns in the public relations War the tobacco industry has been losing for years this isn't a rally about Tobacco Company

it's a rally about real people real people that work in our industry it's about workers and their families and how they have to raise and support those families the angry voices were bused in from the factories of Philip Morris and RJ Reynolds bust in and paid a day's wages to appear as victims of President Clinton's proposed 75 cents a pack tax increase on cigarettes mom

message to the president is like about working people little bit more but losing a lot of jobs to overseas and global economy we got to take care of our own a little bit I feel like they just cranking down tobacco onions are too hard you know I mean that's our freedom the smoke whatever and I feel like they're taking a friend in France not only do the tobacco workers marching today fear the law is closing in on them there is a great sense of outrage that they are being unfairly singled out to Bear the burdens of a health reform plan

that is supposed to benefit everyone I'm in favor of National Health kick National Health Care but we're not going to sing us out tax one industry to try to pay for the whole program if everybody else is not fair the fears for their livelihood are genuine but those jobs have been disappearing for a full decade and the workers who rallied today were really being used according to a Critic of the tobacco industry the tobacco manufacturers are showing an act of desperation today

while they've been laying off tens of thousands of their workers left and right over the past decade they've made billions more cigarettes in the process because they've increased automation now today if we seen them bring the remaining workers up from tobacco manufacturing plants to protest and put a human face on this effort on behalf of the big companies in this country there are two point three million jobs generated by the tobacco industry in this country and that's not just tobacco Growers and tobacco workers those are people in the retail business in the

sale business in the transportation business truck drivers so the effect of this tax will not be contrary to what some people would like you to believe felt just in tobacco land and felt just by tobacco Growers and tobacco workers you're going to see layoffs in the retail industry the wholesale industry the transportation industry it's going to have an effect all across this Country Wide of the Jones have to disappear I mean I can understand they're not going to be doing the same thing that they're going to be doing now that they are selling or retailing or packaging or in any way involving them

ourselves with the sale of tobacco a reasonable assumption would be maybe they'll find another job well we have a the economy is growing somewhat right now but we still have an unemployment problem in this country I don't think our economy right now is that the position where we are willing to turn 275,000 people out of work that's not the way the economy in this country works with the government telling people in what business they should work our economy is based on choice and the free market system want to

I had to work the industry's scariest number is that a 75 cent tax increase will cost two hundred seventy thousand jobs in a ripple effect of losses but only four hundred twenty six thousand people work in all of the nation's tobacco factories and farms and warehouses economists figure cigarette smoking would go down maybe by 12% but demand for us tobacco would drop by much less because almost half of the u.s. crop is now exported

the biggest markets in outside the US for the major tobacco companies are Continental Europe and the United Kingdom that they're growing rapidly in the Asian markets as well and those businesses are enjoying very good volume gains and good earnings increases and a study in today's Journal of the American Medical Association asserts a decline in smoking would not cost jobs so much as move them around as people spend the money on other things

balance we would see relatively little change in aggregate National Employment my suspicion based on our study is that we would see a shift of some jobs from the Southeastern tobacco states to the rest of the economy to the rest of the country the tobacco workers who came to convince the capitol today must know they are in a last-gasp fight the tobacco industry is saying parks department said 16,000 tobacco industry says 20,000 but there were a lot of people

people out there on Capitol Hill today for testing this tax tobacco workers people in related industries does that ever have an impact on you and your colleagues I don't see how anyone is going to be moved by that appeal when we're talking about raising that tax for two purposes one to help fund Health Care in this country and the leading cause of diseases cigarette smoking and secondly to try to

discourage people from smoking because the price is going to go higher in the halls of power those tobacco workers Rome today smoke-filled rooms are a relic of a cliche smoking is banned in 298 Offices here and in all of Congress only 43 members still at MIT the lighting up
from McDonalds to the Pentagon to the state of Maryland the drumbeat to rid the public of smoking intensifies will be back with that story in a moment

this is ABC News Nightline for the past 30 years the actual physical space in which smoking is permitted has shrunk it is gone from broadcast advertising from domestic flights and increasingly from public places once again here's my colleague Chris Puri

the government's war on smoking is now 30 years old a very strong relationship and probably a causal relationship between heart disease and cigarette smoking for the cigarette industry that was just the beginning Marlboro Country good smoke at the end of a working day by 1972 the Marlboro Man along with other cigarette commercials was booted off the airwaves both radio and TV and

it's from the surgeon general's office kept piling up in the 1982 report on cancer we concluded that cigarette smoking was the single greatest cause of excess cancer mortality in the United States in 1983 our report on cardiovascular disease identified cigarette smoking as the most important modifiable risk factor for coronary heart disease in 1984 we identified cigarette smoking as the major cause of chronic obstructive lung disease

disease such as emphysema and chronic bronchitis the 1986 report thoroughly reviewed the evidence that involuntary or passive smoking is harmful concluding that involuntary smoking is a cause of lung cancer in healthy non-smokers that report in part moved Airlines to ban smoking on all domestic flights in 1990 but gentle reminder we do have smoke alarms and all of our lavatories please don't try and sneak in there and get one

thank you once again for smoking or non-smoking none many businesses and restaurants had already begun to segregate smokers or to ban smoking entirely and public service announcements took off the gloves tacking the cigarette manufacturers themselves forget about cancer heart disease and vizima strokes them gentleman we're not in this business for our health

the fact of the matter is we have a legal product which is enjoyed by 50 million people and I don't think federal government ought to be in the business of social engineering and telling those 50 million people what they can do in terms of making their choices are among those that all the time Federal government's taken you know 30 40 50 percent of our of our income for all kinds of things that we have no say over so why not impose it on something that

medical knowledge and so far as it exists today is firmly convinced as cost figures 400,000 lives a year we talked about taking in and applying it someplace let me just tell you that right now cigarette smokers already paid 13 billion that's billion with a be more in taxes than non-smokers do this is not the way to achieve meaningful Health Care reform especially it's unfair it's a regressive tax it falls more heavily on lower and middle-income people

and then others that's not where our government ought to be taken us when they're manufacturing a product that's hazardous in fact kills people that can't be an argument to allow cigarettes to continue at the level of pricing where it it becomes so readily accessible to a lot of young people particularly and and the money that can be raised from tobacco smoking can be used for health care which is a perfect symmetry since it's the leading cause of preventable disease

he's in this country but they would take the position they'd say Henry Waxman you're not really saying that if we if we raise the price of a pack of cigarettes to two dollars or 250 or three dollars you're going to leave us alone you're out to put us out of business soon or late well that's what you want to do is you know I think what we ought to hope for is that the American people go to a smoke free Society but that's going to have to be done voluntarily prohibition won't work we tried that with alcoholic beverages

but we need to discourage people from smoking I just think that ought to be a major part of our public policy agenda because it is important for the health of the American people to encourage smokers not to smoke and non-smokers not to take up this habit the growing government drumbeat on smoking has apparently had some success by 1965 the year after the first surgeon general's report 42% of Americans Smoked by 1991 that number was down

to 26 percent and in just the last few weeks the news for the tobacco industry has not been good McDonald's agreed to ban smoking in all of its 1,400 company-owned restaurants the Utah legislature ban smoking in most places of work and Maryland May soon become the first in the nation to ban all workplace smoking including bars and hotels and the Pentagon announced that grabbing a smoke long the one approved Vice of American Military

we men and women would no longer be permitted in the workplace presumably warzones not included mr. Parrish you folks on the tobacco industry must be feeling a little like Old Testament lepers these days

World closing in on your little bit well we've certainly seen the last few days the last couple of weeks a lot of what I consider to be unfounded and I think the fact show unfounded attacks on our industry we have the health care debate along with the proposed excise tax on cigarettes which we saw 20,000 people in the streets of Washington today marching against that proposed tax you guys gave him the day off and you and your Chowder the buses for him no actually we the way we did it was we provided the

buses for them and we gave him a choice they could work at there and in our instance in Richmond at the factory you're at their regular job or they could be paid a regular days wage and come up to Washington 30 years into the war on smoking the tobacco industry its workers and smokers themselves are under almost constant Siege from the government from society and from science

smokers know it's bad for them most of them will even acknowledge it can kill them they know that secondhand smoke and harm someone they love but they keep on doing it why that part of the story when we come back
it may be banned from more and more places but the addiction to smoking exerts a strong hold and there's new evidence that the tobacco industry may be chemically a stacking the deck

any smoker knows that the kick from a cigarette comes from nicotine a drug found naturally in tobacco even the tobacco companies own researchers say they believe that nicotine is why people smoke the 1992 study co-authored by an RJ Reynolds scientist concluded the beneficial effects of smoking on cognitive performance are a function of nicotine absorbed from cigarette smoke nicotine reduces anxiety and increases mental

oh alertness and it's addicting so addicting according to the Surgeon General that nicotine makes quitting smoking as difficult as quitting cocaine or heroin the Food and Drug Administration regulates nicotine as a drug nicotine patches and nicotine gum are controlled so why hasn't the FDA ever tried to regulate cigarettes according to a letter written by dr. David Kessler commissioner of the FDA the tobacco companies were given the benefit of the

doubt as to whether they intended their products to be used as drugs or their cigarettes were intended to dispense nicotine decades ago in a confidential memo of Philip Morris official called a cigarette pack a storage container for a day supply of nicotine a cigarette was a dispenser for a dose unit of nicotine now the FDA may be changing its view on cigarettes and investigation by the ABC News broadcast they won found that cigarette companies carefully

troll the amount of nicotine in their cigarettes by adding precise amounts of tobacco extract which contains nicotine nicotine and the form of tobacco extract into a product to keep the consumer happy public doesn't know that the industry manipulates nicotine takes it out puts it back in uses it as if it were a sugar being put in candy our sister program they won a couple of days ago

a report on the tobacco industry and the the revelation of that program I must say astonished me and that is that you folks have actually been adding nicotine to the product to the tobacco as a means of causing people to become more addicted to the product it astonished me because that's not right and they one knew that before they aired the show the fact of the matter is number one nicotine is a natural substance in tobacco

so we do absolutely nothing in the manufacturing or processing of our tobacco which results in more nicotine in the final product that's in the naturally occurring tobacco in fact the nicotine levels in the cigarettes we make are lower than in the unprocessed tobacco so for somebody to make those kind of claims is not only inaccurate it's ludicrous and it's outrageous as far as I'm concerned they one had information in advance of that show that contradicted and what the claims that they made and show that they

true is very unfortunate because sir we are trying to get the facts out the facts according to the tobacco companies are that they only add tobacco extract to enhance the flavor not to raise the nicotine content the reason ABC day one report revealed substantial new information that combined with fda's own investigation has brought the whole issue into a new Focus we now know that the tobacco industry consciously

nipple eights the level of nicotine in tobacco products to ensure that they're addictive what that means is it tobacco products don't have to be addictive they're addictive because tobacco manufacturers have consciously chosen to turn I once Agricultural Product into a drug I've just become aware of it when the head of the Food and Drug Administration informed us that he has found substantial amount of evidence indicating that the tobacco industry is adding nicotine to their product Nikki

is the addictive substance the National Institute of drug abuse is called it one of the most highly addictive substances around I just think that unconscionable that they would try to make a product more addictive and keep people who would like to give up smoking and a large number of smokers would like to give it up but they can't do it because this this Hook is been placed on them by the tobacco industry I mean denied of course you know that well it going to Street and they deny it and of course they even the

deny that tobacco smoke causes illness of any sort the Revelation that cigarette companies manipulate the nicotine in their products as lead FDA commissioner Kessler to conclude that cigarette manufacturers May intend that their products contain nicotine to satisfy an addiction on the part of some of their customers and Kessler says it's obvious people buy cigarettes to satisfy their nicotine addiction if the FDA could prove that simple statement it would then be able to regulate cigarettes as

drugs that could ultimately mean in the words of dr. Kessler the removal from the market of tobacco products containing nicotine at levels that cause or satisfy addiction the commissioner told us Congress has got a deal with this question that it clearly he's not about to ban cigarettes that and we're not about to ban cigarettes but we ought to have some regulation on the level of nicotine we had at least warn people on cigarette packs and other places that nicotine is in this product and it's addictive that we've

known for some time but we haven't been able to get that message out Congress will soon hold hearings on the allegations that cigarettes are deliberately designed and marketed to keep smokers hooked even the industry's harshest critics don't believe a ban on cigarette sales is politically possible but that the FDA is even considering such a thing is a sign of how far the tables have turned on the nation's deadliest habit this is Chris Puri for Nightline in Washington
I'll be back in a moment

and that's our report for tonight I'm Ted Koppel in Washington for all of us here at ABC News good night life is a presentation of ABC News more Americans get their news from ABC News than from any other source
